Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of the structural transformation of nickel boride from amorphous to Ni3B crystal. With increasing calcination temperature, boron species diffuse from bulk to the surface, forming boron oxide and boronic acid. (a) X-ray diffraction patterns of Ni3B catalysts pretreated under H2 at different temperatures: 100 °C (100H), 200 °C (200H), 300 °C (300H) and 400 °C (400H). The XRD profiles of Ni3B pretreated under N2 at different temperatures are included in the supplemantary material. With increasing temperature, Ni3B changes from amorphous to crystal structure. (b-e) High-resolution transmission electron microscopy images of (b) Ni3B-100H, (c) Ni3B-200H, (d) Ni3B-300H and (e) Ni3B-400H. It shows Ni3B catalyst changes from amorphous to crystal nature, reflected by the presence of crystal lattice. For Ni3B-400H and Ni3B-400N catalysts, particles exhibit core–shell structure with an amorphous layer, demonstrating morphological reconstruction after pretreatment at higher temperatures. Fig. 2 High-resolution XP spectra of Ni3B catalysts after pretreatment under different conditions: (a) Ni 2p, (b) B 1 s and (c) O 1 s. Fig. 3 Oxidation state and local coordination of the Ni3B catalysts. (a) XANES of Ni K edge of Ni3B catalysts after pretreatment at different temperatures and cooled down to 100 °C. (b) EXAFS spectra in k-space; and (c) R space for Ni K edge of Ni3B catalysts. The fitting parameters are summarized in Table S2 in supplementary material (k range: 3.0–13.0 Å; R range: 1.0–3.0 Å; Hanning window, Δk = 1). Fig. 4 Evolution of reactants and products for the hydrodeoxygenation of phenol at 100 psi H2; 250 °C as a function of w⋅t (mg⋅min). (a) Over Pt/SiO2 catalyst and Ni3B catalyst. In addition, two additional set of reactions were conducted with different feeds over the Ni3B catalyst. In one of them, the reactant was cyclohexanol (c); in the other, the feed contained a (1:1 M) mixture of cyclohexanol and phenol. Fig. 5 Product distribution from the conversion of cyclohexene on Pt/SiO2 (green) and Ni3B (red) catalysts. Only benzene (circles) and cyclohexane (squares) were observed as products at 250 °C and 100 psi H2. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Graphical abstract Modification of earth-abundant metal catalysts with optimized catalytic performance can be potential alternatives to precious metal catalysts for more sustainable processes. Using a chemical reduction method, nickel boride (Ni3B) alloy catalysts were prepared with a Ni/B ratio of 3. Ex-situ and in-situ characterization indicates that the structure of Ni3B changes from amorphous to crystalline with increasing pretreatment temperatures. The presence of B does not seem to alter the electronic properties of Ni. However, after pretreatment, oxidized B species (i.e., BOx and H3BO3) ex-solve from the bulk, leading to the formation of a B-enriched surface. In-situ titration and dehydration reaction experiments demonstrate the presence of acid sites, which play an important promoting role in the hydrogenation of C = C bonds. Moreover, Ni3B catalysts show a remarkable activity towards phenolic ring hydrogenation with the added ability to deoxygenate the secondary products via dehydration on the acid sites. Under water-free reaction conditions, the Ni3B catalysts exhibit similar hydrogenation activity to that of a pure Ni catalyst. Remarkably, the addition of small amounts of water leads to a > 100-fold increase on Ni3B catalysts, while it inhibits the reaction on bare Ni catalyst by blocking active sites. These observations highlight the cooperative role of bifunctional sites in Ni3B catalysts and solvent composition for C = C hydrogenation reactions. Keywords Nickel Boride Bifunctional catalyst HDO of phenol Hydrogenation of cyclohexene Water-assisted hydrogenation water-mediated proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Metal catalysts play an important role in the production of renewable energy, fine chemicals, and pharmaceutical compounds [1–8]. Among them, precious metals have been widely used in many industrial processes due to their high activity, selectivity, and stability [1,4–7]. However, their low natural abundance and potential deleterious effects on biological system are motivating researchers to explore alternative catalysts using elements of higher abundance, lower cost, and overall greater sustainability. Indeed, many classical reactions and challenging transformations that are essential to life are catalyzed by naturally abundant transition metals [9,10]. For example, zinc-containing proteins [11–14], carbonic anhydrase II (HCA II) in red blood cells, catalyze reversible conversion of CO2 and bicarbonate to maintain the proper pH value of cells and human tissues. In enzyme-catalyzed reactions, not only the host–guest interactions between molecules and active sites within a hydrophobic pocket, but also the dynamic protein-water interactions near the active site promote the fast proton-electron transfer during catalysis by forming a robust hydrogen-bonded network with the Zn-bound solvent molecules. As a result, cooperativity between the dynamic protein scaffold and solvent molecules influences enzyme catalysis by manipulating the energies of intermediates and/or transition states, thereby greatly enhancing the rates. Inspired by nature, researchers are striving to advance the integration of naturally abundant transition metals into industrial catalysis. Their focus lies in synthesizing materials with meticulous control over the nanostructure and the local environment surrounding the active site. In addition to modifying the ligands directly bound the catalytic metal center [15–22], one can further mimic the make-up and function of enzymes by altering the local environment and electronic structure of active sites by bonding them to other metals or main-group elements, which may catalyze reaction pathways distinct from those of the parent metal. As one of the most promising naturally abundant transition metal catalysts, metal-boron alloys have displayed catalytic performances comparable to those of precious metals [23,24]. For example, using liquid-phase reduction of metal salts with boron hydride, cobalt or nickel borides can be synthesized with controlled long-range structural disorder and short-range order [25,26]. Their unique physicochemical properties and abundant coordinatively unsaturated sites result in enhanced catalytic performance compared to that of the parent monometallic catalyst. In addition, it has been proposed that the modification of the electronic properties of metals by boron species may alter the adsorption of unsaturated aldehyde molecules and thereby improve the selectivity of CO bond hydrogenation over CC bonds, which is comparable to the behavior of noble metal-based catalysts. Recently, it has been recognized that amorphous metal-boron alloys can become highly crystalline after an annealing treatment [27] and it is known that the bonding structure of amorphous material can be different from its crystalline counterparts, which may lead to differences in catalytic performance. To understand the role of boron in modifying the chemical properties of metals and determine how the local environment surrounding the active site influences catalytic performance, an atomic level characterization of the material structure and a detailed investigation of the reaction mechanism are required. Here, we explore a chemical reduction synthesis process to fabricate amorphous nickel boride alloys under mild conditions followed by thermal treatments. Ex-situ and in-situ characterization reveals that the structure of the Ni3B alloy evolves during thermal treatment under different conditions. As illustrated in Fig. 1 , the high temperature treatment induces crystallization. That is, the synthesized Ni3B changes from its original amorphous state to a crystalline structure that ex-solves boron species, which become enriched on the surface. Interestingly, these surface species become oxidized and subsequently generate acid sites (i.e. BOx, HBOx), creating a metal/acid bifunctional catalyst. Two types of reaction have been investigated. One of them is the hydrodeoxygenation of phenol, and the other is the hydrogenation of cycloalkenes. In the first case, it is observed that the bifunctional nature of the catalyst results in a remarkable activity for hydrodeoxygenation, with a high selectivity towards benzene. In the second case, the bifunctional catalyst exhibits a unique behavior in the presence of small amounts of water. That is, compared to bare Ni, the resulting Ni3B catalysts exhibit similar activity in cyclohexene hydrogenation, when conducted in the absence of water, in a non-polar organic solvent. However, the presence of acid sites (HBOx) on the surface leads to a drastically different catalytic behavior when small amounts of water are added to the reaction mixture. In this instance, the hydrogenation rate of CC bonds undergoes a more than 100-fold increase attributed to the initiation of a water-promoted proton-electron transfer mechanism. Concurrently, the rate on the unmodified Ni catalyst experiences a notable decrease when water is added. These observations demonstrate how the cooperative effect of bifunctional sites (acid/metal) and the presence of water in the solvent near the liquid–solid interface impacts the activity of metal-catalyzed hydrogenation reactions. The combination of materials synthesis and in-situ characterization opens various opportunities to engineering multifunctional materials with precise control and to adjust liquid–solid interfaces, an approach that could be extended to other classes of alloy materials and polar protic solvents with enhanced catalytic performance. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst synthesis 2.1.1 Pt/SiO2 catalyst A 1.0 wt% Pt/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of a SiO2 support (HiSil 210, PPG, SBET = 135 m2/g) with an aqueous solution of H2PtCl6⋅6 H2O (Aldrich), dried overnight at room temperature and then at 110 °C for 12 h, followed by calcination at 400 °C for 4 h. The pre-reduction in the catalyst was conducted in flowing H2 at 300 °C and atmospheric pressure. The quantification of Pt surface metal sites was conducted in a micro pulse system at room temperature. In this experiment, 60 mg of catalyst mass was mixed with 100 mg of glass beads and reduced for 1 h at 250 °C in H2 (60 mL/min). The mixture was then cooled down in helium gas to room temperature. Finally, the fractional uptake of small doses of CO were introduced until saturation to calculate the number of CO moles adsorbed on the surface per unit metal atom (CO/Pt). Additional quantification of the platinum sites was made by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) on a Jeol 2010F. The average particle size obtained from a set of 112 measurements was 17.7 nm, which aligns closely with the dispersion obtained from CO uptake (CO/Pt = 0.11), corresponding to a diameter of 18.5 nm, assuming spherical particles. 2.1.2 Ni3B catalysts The nickel boride catalysts were obtained by a chemical reduction method. In this method, 0.017 mol nickel acetate tetrahydrate was dissolved in 100 mL deionized water; then, 0.07 mol sodium borohydride was dissolved in 30 mL ice-cooled water and added dropwise into the solution under N2 flow. The resulting mixture was kept stirred for another 3 h at room temperature under air-free condition by keeping the N2 flow. The resulting solid was filtered and washed with water and ethanol, followed by vacuum drying overnight at room temperature. Before reaction, the catalyst was pretreated at different temperatures under 20 mL/min H2 flow for 2 h with a heating rate of 1 °C/min. The pretreated catalysts are labeled as 100H, 200H, 300H and 400H, which represent the hydrogen-pretreatment temperatures of 100, 200, 300, and 400 °C, respectively. For the sample pretreated under N2, 50 mL/min N2 flow was used, while the heating rate and time remained the same as the one pretreated in H2. 2.1.3 Ni catalysts The pure nickel catalysts were obtained by the H2 reduction of NiO. In this method, NiO was obtained by calcination of NiC2O4⋅2H2O at 400 °C for 2 h under 50 mL/min air flow with a heating rate of 1 °C/min. To obtain the Ni catalyst, NiO was further reduced by H2 at 400 °C for 2 h under 20 mL/min H2 flow with a heating rate of 1 °C/min. 2.2 Ex-situ XPS analysis X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on a PHI 5800 ESCA system, equipped with an Al Kα X-ray anode. All spectra were referenced to C 1 s at a binding energy (BE) of 284.8 eV. After being reduced in H2 at different temperatures, the sample was transferred and prepared in a glovebox to avoid oxidation of nickel species on the surface. 2.3 In-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) XAS measurements were performed at the Brookhaven National Laboratory using beam line 7-BM at the National Synchrotron Light Source II (NSLS-II). Spectra were collected in transmission mode. A Ni foil reference was scanned simultaneously with the sample for energy calibration. For the as-synthesized Ni3B catalyst, it was diluted by using boron nitride (BN, Sigma-Aldrich). In a typical procedure, 0.005 g catalyst was evenly mixed with 0.1 g BN through grinding. The mixture was then pressed to make a 13 mm-diameter pellet that was loaded to the Nashner-Adler cell. For supported catalysts, the same procedure was performed without using BN to dilute the sample. 20 scans were taken at room temperature in a stream of 20 mL/min He. Samples were then reduced at different temperatures (100 °C, 200 °C, 300 °C and 400 °C) for 1 h in a stream of 2 mL/min H2 mixed with 18 mL/min He. Athena and Artemis software, parts of the Demeter package, were used for analysis of the EXAFS data. Pre-processing of data included alignment, edge calibration, normalization, background subtraction, and conversion of data into a chi file for data fitting was performed with Athena. The edge energy, determined by the first inflection point of the absorption edge of the reference Ni foil, was calibrated to the reported Ni K-edge energy, 8332.8 eV. 2.4 Catalytic measurements Hydrodeoxygenation of phenol and intermediate compounds was used as a probe reaction to evaluate the catalytic activity of bifunctional Ni3B catalysts comparatively with a 1 % by weight platinum on silica catalyst. The reaction was conducted in a 50 mL Mini Bench Top Parr high pressure reactor. In each run, the Ni3B catalyst was placed in the reactor vessel with 25 mL of dodecane solvent. The reactor was purged with at least 400 psi H2 three times to remove all air. Then, the pressure was raised to 100 psi in H2, and the temperature was set to 250 °C while stirring at 700 rpm. After one hour, 10 mL of a 0.05 M solution of phenol and/or cyclohexanol in dodecane was placed into a 50 mL feed cylinder, pressurized to 500 psi with nitrogen and injected into the reaction cylinder to a final pressure of 500 psi to ensure an accurately determined zero-time for the start of the reaction period. After the initial injection, the reaction temperature returned to the set point within 5 min. After 0.5 h of reaction, the reactor vessel was rapidly cooled, and the liquid phase and catalyst were separated. The liquid-product mixture was identified on a Shimadzu QP2010S gas chromatograph/mass spectrometer (GC–MS) and quantified on an Agilent 6890 gas chromatograph, equipped with flame ionization detector (GC-FID). Similarly, hydrogenation of cyclohexene (anhydrous, Sigma-Aldrich) with and without addition of water was evaluated in a 150 mL Mini Bench Top Parr high-pressure reactor. In each run, 10 mg of catalyst was dispersed into 50 mL dodecane solvent (anhydrous, Sigma-Aldrich) and placed in the reactor vessel. The system was purged with 400 psi H2 for three times to remove air inside. Then, the pressure was raised to 100 psi in H2, and the temperature increased to 100 °C while stirring at 500 rpm. After 1 h, 1.0 mL cyclohexene reactant mixed in 9.0 mL dodecane solvent was placed into a 30 mL feed cylinder, pressurized to 500 psi and injected into the reactor to ensure an accurately determined zero-time for the start of the reaction period. After 0.5 h reaction, the liquid and solid mixture was separated by centrifugation. For the experiment performed in the presence of water, a small amount of water was mixed with the solution containing catalyst and solvent before the reaction. For in-situ measurement of active-site by titration during catalysis [28], 0.4 mmol/gcata pyridine were mixed with the feed during thehydrogenation reaction at 100 °C. The liquid product mixture was identified on a Shimadzu QP2010S gas chromatograph/mass spectrometer (GC–MS) and quantified on an Agilent 6890 gas chromatograph, equipped with flame ionization detector (GC-FID). For cyclopentanol dehydration reaction, a similar procedure was followed. The reaction temperature was 200 °C. For in-situ measurement of active-site by titration during catalysis [28], 0.4 mmol/gcata pyridine were mixed with the feed during thehydrogenation reaction at 100 °C. 2.5 Computational calculations All the calculations were performed with spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) as implemented in the Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP) [29,30]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) method was used to describe the interactions between ions and electrons [31] with the exchange–correlation functional of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [32,33]. The plane wave energy cutoff was set to be 400 eV. The convergence tolerances for atomic force and total energy were 0.02 eV/Å and 10-5 eV, respectively. The energy and structure optimization were carried out at Γ point only. A sufficiently large vacuum layer was employed along z-direction of the Ni surface in the models to minimize the interactions between periodic images. The van der Waals (vdW) weak interactions were taken into account using the DFT-D3 method [34]. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were performed at room temperature with a NVT ensemble. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural evolution of Ni3B catalysts after pretreatment X-ray diffraction (XRD, Fig. 1) shows that after a low temperature pretreatment (<300 °C) under H2 or N2 flow the synthesized nickel boride exhibits an amorphous structure (see Figure S1 in supplementary material). By contrast, when the temperature is higher than about 300 °C, a crystalline phase of Ni3B is observed, which is consistent with the inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis conducted on this sample that yielded a Ni:B ratio of 3:1. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm analysis indicates that after high temperature pretreatment the catalysts have a specific surface area of ∼ 10 m2/g (see Table 3). Due to the overlapping of Ni(111) and Ni3B(102) facets at 44.8° and 44.9°, the presence of Ni metal cannot be excluded. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM; Figure S2 ) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM; Fig. 1) reveal that the Ni3B catalysts are composed of nanoparticles with diameters ranging from 5 to 30 nm. Consistent with the XRD analysis, the particles change from amorphous to crystal nature with increased pretreatment temperature, which is reflected by the presence of a crystal lattice in HRTEM images for Ni3B-300H, Ni3B-400H and Ni3B-400 N ( Figure S2 in the supplementary material). Moreover, HRTEM shows that an amorphous layer with a thickness ∼ 1 nm emerged after the catalysts were pretreated at high temperatures (300 – 400 °C) and air exposure. This layer could represent the formation of amorphous boron oxide species, as reported in a previous study [23]. Furthermore, XPS analysis, as discussed in the following section, also demonstrated the surface enrichment of boron oxide species after pretreatment. 3.2 Effect of temperature on ex-solution of B species from the bulk structure Ex-situ XPS and in-situ EXAFS measurements were performed to investigate the local environment surrounding active sites. Fig. 2 a shows that oxidized Ni species, such as Ni-O and Ni-OH, are dominant after pretreatment under H2 at 100 °C [26,35]. As the pretreatment temperature increases, only metallic Ni is detected. Likewise, the pretreatment under N2 at 400 °C also leads to the formation of metallic Ni, which may be because of the reducing property of boride that favors formation of Ni0 by reacting with oxygen species (see Figure S3 in supplementary material). In addition, the low electronegativity of Ni(1.91) compared to that of B(2.04) may also favor the oxygen transfer from Ni to B at high temperatures. As a result, different oxidation states of B were observed for the catalysts pretreated at different temperatures. Fig. 2b indicates that the surface contains both B–O and metal–B bonds [23,26,35]. It is observed that, at all temperatures, the boron on the catalyst surfaces mainly remains as oxidized B species. Table 1 summarizes the surface compositions of Ni3B catalysts from the XPS analysis. With increasing temperature, not only the oxidation states of surface species, but also the compositions of Ni3B catalysts change. Boron species tend to ex-solvate from the bulk to the surface, a conclusion supported by the increased B/Ni ratio on the pretreated catalysts. Fig. 2c reveals the presence of O–H species on the surface. With increasing pretreatment temperature, O 1 s slightly shifts to higher binding energies, which could be ascribed to the transfer of oxygen atoms from Ni–O to B–O. The stronger boron and oxygen interaction leads to a higher binding energy of O. In-situ XAS measurements also demonstrate the structural changes occurring during pretreatment. Fig. 3 a shows the Ni K-absorption edge of the normalized X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra. It reveals that the white lines of Ni3B catalysts after pretreatment at different temperatures are not significantly different from the metallic nickel reference material (foil). This is also consistent with the ex-situ XPS analysis that the presence of B species does not change the electronic properties of Ni. However, it is known that the spatial probe of XPS (and particularly XAS) is not strictly limited to the top surface, but in the best case near-surface. The extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) analysis depicted in Fig. 3 b and c indicates that the Ni–Ni bond at ∼ 2.15 Å dominates in the R-space with a small fraction of Ni-B bond at 1.7 Å for Ni3B catalysts pretreated at lower temperatures (100–300 °C) [23,26,35–37]. The Ni3B catalyst pretreated at 400 °C is almost identical to the reference Ni foil. It should be noted that the typical Ni–O distance is ∼ 1.5 Å, which is close to the Ni–B distance. For example, Masa et al. [26] have synthesized Ni3B using the same chemical reduction method. That is, nickel salt (NiCl2) reacts with sodium borohydride (NaBH4) in water under inert gas environment. EXAFS measurements show the presence of Ni–O, Ni–B and Ni–Ni bonds within the nickel borides pretreated at different temperatures. Between Ni–O and Ni–Ni peaks, an extra peak refers to the presence of B in a local Ni environment. Therefore, we cannot exclude some contribution of O in the first coordination shell of Ni atoms. With increasing pretreatment temperature, the fitting results shown in Table 2 indicates that the contribution from Ni–B bonds decreases, while the contribution from Ni–Ni bonds increases, which is also reflected by the spectra in k space. That is, both Ni–B and Ni–Ni contribute to the fitting of EXAFS spectra of Ni3B catalyst pretreated in the low temperature range (100 and 200 °C). After the sample was pretreated at 300 °C and 400 °C, the contributions of Ni-B paths decrease significantly, while the contributions of the Ni-Ni paths increase. After the 400 °C pretreatment, the spectra in both k- and R- spaces are identical to the pure Ni foil, indicating the local coordination of Ni atoms changes from the B atoms to Ni atoms due to the ex-solution of B species. Correspondingly, the coordination number of B decreases, while the coordination number of Ni increases with increasing pretreatment temperature. A higher pretreatment temperature also leads to the increased particle size, as indicated by the increased peak intensity in k space as a function of temperature. This is also in agreement with the TEM analysis, which gives evidence for increased particle size of Ni3B with temperature. 3.3 Acid density of bronsted acid site (H3BO3) on the catalyst Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra were collected to confirm the presence of H3BO3 species on the catalyst surface. As shown in Figure S4 in supplementary material, while the bands observed at 3400 ∼ 3000 cm−1 are clearly attributed to OH stretching vibrational modes of Brønsted acid sites [38,39] the low intensity of these bands indicates a modest density of acid sites. Therefore, to better quantify this acid density, measurements of cyclopentanol dehydration reaction rate were obtained on these Ni3B catalysts and compared to the activity obtained on a catalyst of known acid density, i.e., MCM-41 functionalized with sulfonic acid groups (See Table S3 in supplementary material) [38,39]. Since the activity per site of these two materials should be comparable, by comparing the reaction rates, the acid density of Ni3B catalysts can be estimated. As summarized in Table 3 , these estimates indicate that all the catalysts exhibited acid densities in the range of 1–4 μmol/g, or 0.05–0.15 sites/nm2. Collectively, these results indicate that Ni3B catalysts have metal/acid sites bifunctionality which can exhibit unique catalytic behavior. The presence of boron species on the catalyst surface does not seem to alter the electronic property of the metal site, as indicated by ex-situ XPS and in-situ XAS analyses. However, due to the stronger attraction of boron to oxygen, which leads to electron transfer from B to O and thus unoccupied p orbitals of B, the surface-enriched B(OH)x species may generate an acid site that influences the catalytic performance of these Ni3B catalysts. 3.4 Catalytic activity of bifunctional Ni3B catalysts. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of phenolics is a very important reaction with applications in biomass conversion that has been observed to occur efficiently on catalysts exhibiting bifunctional metal/acid characteristics [40,41]. Therefore, we chose to run the HDO of phenol in the liquid phase as a test reaction for the Ni3B(400 N) catalyst and compared its performance to that of a monofunctional Pt/SiO2 catalyst. The product distribution was followed as a function of the extent of reaction in the batch reactor. To minimize the effect of deactivation, the evolution of products was determined at short reaction times and expressed as a function of the product w⋅t (catalyst mass × reaction time). As previously described [42], the evolution of reactant and product concentrations in a batch reactor is always a function of the product k⋅t, where k = kw⋅w, being kw the rate constant per unit mass and w the catalyst mass. For example, for a first order reaction the reactant concentration is Ci = Ci0e-kt or Ci = Ci0e-kw wt . Therefore, to analyze the reaction kinetics, it is equivalent to use any of the two following differential equations: (1) d C i d t = r i (at constant w) (2) d C i d w = r i (at constant t). As summarized in Fig. 4 a and b, on both Pt/SiO2 and Ni3B catalysts, phenol is directly hydrogenated to cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol, which subsequently can undergo secondary reaction steps. By contrast, the deoxygenated products can be formed as primary or secondary products. For example, benzene can be formed by direct HDO of phenol, but also as a secondary product following dehydration of cyclohexanol to cyclohexene and subsequent dehydrogenation. The possible reaction paths for the conversion of phenol are illustrated in Scheme 1 . By assuming any reactions with Keq > 50 to be irreversible, and all reactions pseudo-first order in the reactant intermediate, with the exception of cyclohexanol to cyclohexene, which is zeroth order (See Table S3). we have used the following rate expressions to fit the data: (3) - r P h e 1 = k ′ f P h e 1 C Phe - k r P h e 1 C One (4) - r P h e 2 = k ′ f P h e 2 C Phe - k r P h e 2 C Ol (5) - r O n e 3 = k ′ f O n e 3 C One - k r O n e 3 C Ol (6) - r B e n 4 = k ' f B e n 4 C Ben (7) - r E n e 5 = k f E n e 5 C Ene (8) - r E n e 6 = k ′ f E n e 6 C Ene (9) - r P h e 7 = k ′ f P h e 7 C Phe (10) - r O l 8 = k f O l 8 where the kfin are the forward rate constants (species i, step n), krin the reverse rate constants (species i, step n), and k’fin the rate constants with the rate dependance on hydrogen incorporated. The hydrogen contribution to each reaction rate remains constant for each case since all runs were conducted under the same hydrogen pressure (100 psi) and this pressure did not change significantly during the reaction period. Where possible, the forward rate constant kfin was calculated from k’fin and the reverse rate constant. To enhance the robustness of the model and substantiate the physical significance of the derived kinetic parameters, two additional reactions were conducted on the Ni3B catalyst using different feeds. In each case, the evolution of Ci was evaluated as a function of w⋅t (mass × time). The corresponding fittings were achieved by simultaneously utilizing data from the three different feeds with a single set of kinetic parameters. Specifically, for a given reaction step (e.g., benzene-to-cyclohexane) appearing in each of the three cases, the same set of parameters (K4 and kB en 4 ) was employed. In the dataset depicted in Fig. 4c, cyclohexanol was employed as a feed. The primary product in this case was cyclohexanone, with benzene and cyclohexane appearing as subsequent products. In Fig. 4d, a 1:1 M mixture of cyclohexanol and phenol was used as a feed. Similar to the phenol case (Fig. 4a), the main products were cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol, with cyclohexanol initially consumed and then increasing. Subsequently, cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone were both consumed at a lower rate, leading to the production of deoxygenated products (benzene and cyclohexane). To derive all the kinetic parameters outlined in Scheme 1, equilibrium constant values (K1–K7 ) were initially obtained from H, S, G thermochemical data (See Table S4 and S5). The eight forward rate constant values (kf ) were then treated as adjustable parameters to simultaneously fit the experimental values of Ci as a function of w.t for the three different sets in Fig. 4a for Pt/SiO2 and Fig. 4 (b, c, d) for Ni3B. The calculated concentrations resulting from the fitting in the four reaction sets are depicted in Fig. 4 as continuous solid lines together with the corresponding experimental values. The kinetic parameters resulting from the fit are summarized in Table 4 , along with the corresponding thermodynamic equilibrium constants. As indicated in Table 4, the Ni3B catalyst is active for converting phenol into both cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone through direct hydrogenation of the phenolic ring. It also catalyzes the reaction from cyclohexanone to cyclohexanol and quickly reaches equilibrium. As expected from the characterization results, the presence of BAS resulting from oxidized B species on the surface provides the necessary acidity for the observed dehydration activity. Under the same reaction conditions (100 psi H2; 250 °C) the initial rate of phenol hydrogenation is significantly higher on the Ni3B catalyst than on Pt. In fact, normalizing to exposed metal atoms (Ni or Pt), the estimated intrinsic activity of the Ni3B nanoparticles was estimated to be 30 mol/mol Nis sec, much higher than that on Pt/SiO2, which was about 2 mol/mol Pts sec. While not as significant, the initial rate of hydrodeoxygenation of phenol over the Ni3B catalyst was also higher than over the Pt/SiO2 catalyst. The estimated intrinsic activity of the Ni3B catalyst was 1.6 mol/mol Nisurf sec, compared to 0.7 mol/mol Ptsurf sec over Pt/SiO2, where mol Nisurf and mol Ptsurf represent the moles of surface sites of Ni and Pt, respectively. At the same time, while Ni3B is also capable of direct deoxygenation, its high activity for phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexanol (metal function) and dehydration of cyclohexanol to cyclohexene (acid function) makes this bifunctional mechanism the predominant path to deoxygenated products. Notably, while hydrogenation/dehydration is the dominant path on Ni3B catalysts, cyclohexene is almost undetected during reaction. The reason is the very high activity of this catalyst to convert cyclohexene into benzene and cyclohexane (see in Table 4 , kfEne5, kfEne6 ≫ kfOl8 ). As a result, the reverse reaction for step 8 has been neglected since the surface concentration of cyclohexene is exceedingly small. This behavior contrasts with the case of Pt/SiO2, which showed no dehydration activity (see in Table 4, kOl8 = 0) and the deoxygenation only occurs via direct deoxygenation, as previously reported [43]. It is noteworthy that, contrary to the behavior of the conventional Pt/SiO2 catalyst, on which the hydrogenation/dehydrogenation of the non-oxygenated compounds is comparatively rapid, on the Ni3B catalyst the benzene-cyclohexane is not kinetically relevant at these reaction conditions, indicating that the majority of benzene in the reaction is either directly derived from phenol or from cyclohexene. Additionally, the observed cyclohexane derives almost entirely from cyclohexene. Another interesting observation is the significant differences observed in the selectivity of non-oxidized products between the two catalysts. Fig. 5 illustrates the product distribution obtained during the conversion of cyclohexene. When feeding cyclohexene at 250 °C and 100 psi H2 over the Pt/SiO2 and Ni3B catalysts, the only two products observed were benzene and cyclohexane. However, at any given conversion the percentage of each one drastically changed between the two catalysts. While in both cases, the production of cyclohexane is higher than that of benzene, the benzene/cyclohexane ratio is near an order of magnitude higher on Ni3B than on Pt/SiO2 at any conversion level (see Fig. 5). Aspen Plus has been used to calculate the equilibrium of cyclohexene dehydrogenation (formation of benzene) and hydrogenation (formation of cyclohexane) reactions. In fact, within experimental error, the benzene/cyclohexane ratios observed on Pt/SiO2 are the same as those obtained from Aspen simulations. However, the ratios observed over Ni3B catalysts are far from the simulated result, which agrees with the concept that these catalysts are selective for the production of benzene from cyclohexene and, as mentioned the interconversion between benzene and cyclohexane is almost negligible. When fitting the reaction data at conditions where hydrodeoxygenation reactions proceed at relevant rates. This is further supported by the fact that the initial rate of benzene hydrogenation is more than an order of magnitude lower than the initial rate of cyclohexene hydrogenation/dehydrogenation. (See Table S6 in the supplementary material). This selectivity to benzene could be due to site-specific chemistry, which has precedence for cyclohexene disproportionation [44]. 3.5 Water promoted CC hydrogenation on Ni3B catalyst Following the interesting differences observed between Pt and Ni3B catalysts for the conversion of phenol, we further compared the hydrogenation activity of these catalysts using cyclohexene as a reactant representing a CC bond compound. As depicted in Fig. 6 , the rates of cyclohexene (ENE) hydrogenation in dodecane solvent on Ni3B catalysts are nearly identical to those on the pure Ni catalyst (i.e., 1–2 x10-3 mol/h/m2). The cyclohexene hydrogenation rates on different catalysts under water-free reaction conditions are summarized in Table S8 in SI. This suggests that the presence of B species does not markedly augment the catalytic activity of CC hydrogenation, which is consistent with the absence of any electronic modification of Ni by the presence of B, as inferred from XPS and XAS analysis. Notably, a distinct behavior emerges when small amounts of water (<0.5 mL) are introduced into a 60 mL non-polar solvent (dodecane in this instance). While on the pure Ni catalyst, the hydrogenation rates decrease as the amount of added water increases, on Ni3B catalysts, the rates experience a remarkable increase (>100-fold) when less than 0.08 mL of water is added. With a higher amount of water, the rates subsequently decrease, but even under these conditions, the hydrogenation rates on all Ni3B catalysts remain higher than those obtained under water-free reaction conditions. The disparate catalytic performances of Ni3B and Ni catalysts can be attributed to the presence of B species at the surface. As illustrated in Fig. 6c, the hydrogenation rates per surface area exhibit a dramatic increase with the density of surface B. Given that the presence of B does not significantly alter the electronic properties of the surface metal, the enhanced hydrogenation rate in the presence of water should be ascribed to the acidic properties of the Ni3B catalysts. Previous studies have shown that the presence of water molecules helps shuttling the proton from a Brønsted acid site on zeolite to CC bond by forming hydrated hydronium ions [45–47]. Water provides an additional reaction pathway with a lower activation energy and thereby an enhanced hydrogenation rate of the aromatic ring of phenol is observed. Likewise, the water-assisted proton-electron transfer mechanism has been proposed in water promoted CO bond hydrogenation reactions [48]. In this case, structural characterization demonstrates the formation of Brønsted acid sites during synthesis/reaction. With increasing pretreatment temperature, the increased density of B leads to a higher density of Brønsted acid site (e. g. H3BO3). Particularly, in the presence of water, it can react with boron oxide to form H3BO3. As a result, an increase in reaction rate is observed with increasing pretreatment temperature due to the enriched B species formed on the surface, which interacts with water and promotes the reaction. Likewise, the catalyst pretreated under N2 at 400 °C ( Figure S6 in the supplementary material) exhibits similar catalytic performance as the one pretreated under H2 at 400 °C, indicating that the pretreatment temperature plays an important role in both crystallization process and catalytic reactions. 3.6 Cooperative roles of water and acid sites in Ni3B catalyzed cyclohexene hydrogenation reaction To further examine the influence of Brønsted acid sites on the catalytic activity of the Ni3B catalysts, in-situ titration with pyridine was carried out during reaction. In Fig. 7 , it is observed that a small quantity of pyridine has no discernible effect on the activity of Ni3B catalysts in water-free reaction conditions. This suggests that the presence of pyridine does not result in competitive adsorption with the reactant, which could otherwise lead to a reduction in activity. Conversely, under the same conditions, the addition of an equivalent amount of pyridine significantly diminishes the catalyst's activity in the presence of water. This implies the selective adsorption of pyridine on the acid sites, suppressing the catalytic activity of Ni3B. Therefore, the presence of B in Ni3B catalysts primarily functions as an acid site, working collaboratively with the metal site in the CC hydrogenation reaction. The introduction of a small quantity of water facilitates the connection between the two catalytic sites, promoting the reaction through a proton-electron transferring mechanism. As a result of pretreatment at elevated temperatures, the ex-solution of element B yields a catalyst with an increased surface density of B, consequently leading to enhanced promotion by water. Notably, the addition of as little as 0.05 mL of water to 50 mL of solvent significantly amplifies the hydrogenation activity. It is conceivable that, owing to its hydrophilic nature, the Ni3B surface attracts water molecules. Despite the low concentration of water in the bulk liquid, the surface experiences an enrichment in density of water molecules. Our prior ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations for a comparably hydrophilic system, such as sulfonated silica, support this observation. Even with a minimal number of water molecules in the organic solvent bulk, the density of water molecules is substantially augmented near the hydrophilic surface [39]. As illustrated in Scheme 2 , boron oxide can react with water, forming different surface boric species, such as metaboric acid (HBO2), boric acid B(OH)3, and borates B(OH)4 - [49] In liquid environment, B(OH)3/H2O form stronger H-bonds with boric acid as the H-bond donor than it as a H-bond acceptor. Previous MD simulations suggest there are 5 H-bonded water molecules (either H-bond acceptors or donors) in the solvation shell of B(OH)3 [50]. In our calculations, we introduce five or eight water molecules (Fig. 8 ). The B(OH)3, in the absence of water, adsorbs in a flat configuration with the plane in parallel with the Ni surface; however, interaction with water drives the B(OH)3 to a tilted configuration, which is more stable by about 0.2 eV than the flat configuration. We observe at least four H-bonds are formed between water and B(OH)3. We further calculate the deprotonation energy (DPE). In the absence of water, the DPE value is 15.3 eV. Introduction of water does not change the DPE much. Due to the different water-acid configurations, the DPE changes between 15.2 and 16.1 eV within 1 ps. We anticipate this variation may further increase if we extend the simulation time. Finally, we calculate the Ni/B(OH)3 with a surface adsorbed cyclohexene; the DFT-optimized structure (Fig. 8c) shows a H-bond between an acid-bound water and cyclohexene CC double bond with a distance of 2.7 Å. Therefore, we anticipate that, in addition to the acidity introduced to the metal surface creating bifunctional sites with unique HDO activity, the water bonding with the boric acid at the interface also promotes the CC bond hydrogenation reaction through coupled proton-electron transfer or concerted proton-hydride transfer. The exact nature of the boric species at the metal-water interface during the reaction and detailed reaction mechanism remain to be explored in a future study through a combined,rigorousstructural characterization and computational simulations. 4 Conclusions In this study, the chemical reduction method was employed to modify the catalytic properties of earth-abundant-metal-based catalysts. In comparison to a pure Ni catalyst, the introduction of boron species onto the synthesized catalysts does not induce significant changes in the electronic properties of Ni. Consequently, under water-free reaction conditions, the Ni3B catalysts demonstrate a comparable reaction rate for CC hydrogenation to that of the parent Ni catalyst. However, alterations in the structure of Ni3B catalysts occur during pretreatment. Elevated pretreatment temperatures promote the crystallization process of Ni3B catalysts, leading to the ex-solution of B species from the bulk to the surface. Consequently, the resulting boron-enriched surface modifies the catalytic performance of Ni3B catalysts by providing additional functionalities that collaborate with the metal sites. The Ni3B catalyst shows an ability to both directly deoxygenate and hydrodeoxygenate phenol due to its bifunctionality, in contrast to a monofunctional Pt/SiO2 catalyst which only directly deoxygenates phenol to benzene. The Ni3B catalyst also shows a rapid interconversion between cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone, approaching equilibrium between the two rapidly at the reaction conditions. Additionally, Ni3B shows an increased selectivity to benzene from cyclohexene in comparison to a traditional monofunctional catalyst, in this case Pt/SiO2. In the presence of water, the reaction rate on the Ni catalyst gradually decreases with increasing water content, whereas the reaction rates on Ni3B catalysts experience a substantial increase by more than two orders of magnitude (>100-fold). This enhancement can be attributed to the water-assisted proton transfer mechanism. That is, water molecules can act as bridges between the acid sites and the CC group, facilitating the transfer of protons from a Brønsted acid site to the C atoms in the CC bond, thereby promoting the hydrogenation reaction. These observations offer insights that may serve as guidelines for optimizing catalytic performance through a combination of catalyst synthesis and solvent selection. coredata.dc:description: Modification of earth-abundant metal catalysts with optimized catalytic performance can be potential alternatives to precious metal catalysts for more sustainable processes. Using a chemical reduction method, nickel boride (Ni3B) alloy catalysts were prepared with a Ni/B ratio of 3. Ex-situ and in-situ characterization indicates that the structure of Ni3B changes from amorphous to crystalline with increasing pretreatment temperatures. The presence of B does not seem to alter the electronic properties of Ni. However, after pretreatment, oxidized B species (i.e., BOx and H3BO3) ex-solve from the bulk, leading to the formation of a B-enriched surface. In-situ titration and dehydration reaction experiments demonstrate the presence of acid sites, which play an important promoting role in the hydrogenation of C = C bonds. Moreover, Ni3B catalysts show a remarkable activity towards phenolic ring hydrogenation with the added ability to deoxygenate the secondary products via dehydration on the acid sites. Under water-free reaction conditions, the Ni3B catalysts exhibit similar hydrogenation activity to that of a pure Ni catalyst. Remarkably, the addition of small amounts of water leads to a > 100-fold increase on Ni3B catalysts, while it inhibits the reaction on bare Ni catalyst by blocking active sites. These observations highlight the cooperative role of bifunctional sites in Ni3B catalysts and solvent composition for C = C hydrogenation reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Bifunctional metal–acid sites on nickel boride catalysts: Phenol hydrodeoxygenation and water-promoted C = C hydrogenation
